H0.text: During a space mission, astronauts perform the experiment to obtain data to test a hypothesis, even though scientists have predicted the outcome.

H1.text: To make a complete observation, astronauts perform the experiment in space even though scientists have already predicted the outcome.

H2.text: To make a report of the procedures, astronauts conduct experiments during a space mission even though scientists have already predicted the outcomes.

H3.text: To make a hypothesis understandable is why astronauts perform the experiment in space, even when scientists have already predicted its outcome, allowing them to confirm the prediction and communicate it clearly.

A4.text: It is essential that the outcome of testing such a prediction be currently unknown. If the outcome is already known, it is called a consequence and should have already been considered while formulating the hypothesis.

A5.text: Only in this case does a successful outcome increase the probability that the hypothesis is true. If the outcome is already known, it is called a consequence and should have already been considered while formulating the hypothesis.

A6.text: If one cannot assess the predictions by observation or by experience, the hypothesis needs to be tested by others providing observations.

A7.text: The scientific method involves experimentation to test the ability of some hypothesis to adequately answer the question under investigation.
